G.L. c. 208, \u00a728.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody/parenting time judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, and the Court’s general equity jurisdiction under G.L. c. 215, §6, and applicable case law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).

G.L. c. 215, \u00a76.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody/parenting time judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, and the Court’s general equity jurisdiction under G.L. c. 215, §6, and applicable case law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody/parenting time judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, and the Court’s general equity jurisdiction under G.L. c. 215, §6, and applicable case law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas is a divorce and removal case, not a post‑judgment complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, §28. It interprets the removal statute, G.L. c. 208, §30, and articulates the ‘real advantage’/best‑interests standard for a custodial parent seeking to relocate children, but it does not itself arise as or discuss the procedural vehicle of a complaint for modification under §28 or the court’s equity jurisdiction under G.L. c. 215, §6. Thus it is relevant authority on relocation standards, not on the characterization of the action as a complaint for modification pursuant to §28 and §6.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)….”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody/parenting time judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, and the Court’s general equity jurisdiction under G.L. c. 215, §6, and applicable case law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Rosenthal as authority in a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the court’s equity jurisdiction, alongside Yannas. Rosenthal squarely addresses a complaint for modification of a prior custody judgment under § 28, clarifies the required showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances for custody modification, and applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ standard to a removal request. Thus it is an appropriate and accurate case to cite for a custody/parenting-time modification/removal complaint framed under these statutes and cases.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 ("the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children").

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester Probate and Family Court because this Court issued the existing custody and parenting time orders concerning the minor child and because the child resides within this Court’s jurisdiction.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosen v. Rosen concerns child support arrearages, equitable credits, contempt, and college expense contributions. It does not address venue, the proper county for filing, or any jurisdictional analysis related to the Worcester Probate and Family Court or to where a child resides. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that venue is proper in Worcester because that court issued the prior custody orders and the child resides in its jurisdiction.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: At the time the 2021 Custody Order was entered, the Court found, based on the information then before it, that both parents were stable and that they could effectively co‑parent under a shared legal custody arrangement, and that the Defendant’s weekend parenting time was in the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a 2021 custody order finding that both parents were stable, could effectively co‑parent under shared legal custody, and that the defendant’s weekend parenting time was in the child’s best interests. Rolde v. Rolde is a 1981 Massachusetts Appeals Court decision about a different family; it upholds an award of sole (not shared) custody, finds the parents could not cooperate, and approves *reducing* the father’s visitation. It neither involves a 2021 order nor contains findings that both parents were stable and able to effectively co‑parent under shared legal custody with weekend time being in the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’ … [T]he judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order.”

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time for Ethan pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA), G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s home state.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of an existing custody or parenting time judgment requires a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order, and (2) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of alimony and child support, not modification of custody or parenting time. It clearly states that modification of a support judgment requires a material change in circumstances, but it does not discuss custody standards or the best-interests-of-the-child test in the context of modifying custody or parenting time orders. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific custody/parenting time modification standard in the proposition.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.”

Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.raw_text: Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130 (2004)
Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of an existing custody or parenting time judgment requires a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order, and (2) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.
Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.support_reasoning: The opinion in Cooper v. Cooper concerns modification of child support and alimony, not custody or parenting time. While it discusses the need to show a material change in circumstances for modification of support, it does not address standards for modifying custody or parenting time or tie such modifications to a best-interests-of-the-child analysis. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about custody/parenting time modification standards under Massachusetts law.
Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.relevant_excerpt: “However, ‘where the trial court has previously passed on the issue of alimony in the divorce judgment, the correct course of action ... is the post-divorce complaint for modification, implicating the traditional test of a material change in circumstances.’ Buckley v. Buckley, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 716, 719 (1997).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The “paramount concern” of the Court in all custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and repeatedly references the child’s best interests, but it does not use language like "paramount concern" or otherwise expressly elevate the best interests standard in the categorical way stated in the proposition. Its focus is on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects within the existing best-interests framework, not on announcing a general doctrinal statement that best interests are the court’s paramount concern in all custody and parenting time determinations. Thus, it does not clearly serve as authority for the exact proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. The Appeals Court gave great weight to this court’s Gender Bias Study... particularly to the recommendation... that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The “paramount concern” of the Court in all custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the longstanding Massachusetts standard that custody decisions are governed by the best interests of the child and quotes prior precedent stating that the best interests of the children are the court’s "paramount concern." It relies on Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas and related cases to reaffirm that this is the controlling, overarching principle in custody determinations, directly matching the proposition cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)…; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a731.proposition: The “paramount concern” of the Court in all custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to impose conditions, restrictions, or supervision on parenting time where necessary to protect a child’s physical safety and emotional welfare, including orders related to substance use, supervision by a third party, or limitations on overnights, so long as such conditions are reasonably related to the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth in a joint physical custody context and the application of the “best interests” test under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not discuss the Probate and Family Court’s equitable power to impose conditions, restrictions, supervision, or substance-use‑related requirements on parenting time or to limit overnights. The court’s analysis is about whether relocation is in the children’s best interests, not about crafting conditional visitation or supervised parenting orders, so it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to impose conditions, restrictions, or supervision on parenting time where necessary to protect a child’s physical safety and emotional welfare, including orders related to substance use, supervision by a third party, or limitations on overnights, so long as such conditions are reasonably related to the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial mother to move back to Massachusetts. It does not discuss the scope of a court’s equitable power to impose conditions, restrictions, or supervision on parenting time, nor does it address orders about substance use, supervised visits, or overnights. Because those issues are outside the opinion’s analysis, the case does not provide authority for the broad equitable‑conditions proposition stated.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. ... As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is 'free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].' ... Once it was established that the mother had relocated prior to an adjudication of paternity, the judge had no grounds to examine the reasons for or sincerity of the mother’s move."

Diaz v. Diaz, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 1122 (20.raw_text: Diaz v. Diaz, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 1122 (2021) (Rule 1:28 decision)
Diaz v. Diaz, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 1122 (20.proposition: A material change in circumstances exists where facts arising after the entry of the prior order demonstrate that the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests or poses an unreasonable risk to the child’s welfare.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A material change in circumstances exists where facts arising after the entry of the prior order demonstrate that the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests or poses an unreasonable risk to the child’s welfare.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the proper criteria for an initial custody determination in a divorce judgment, emphasizing that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and best interests. It does not address modification standards or what constitutes a “material change in circumstances” after a prior order, nor does it discuss post-judgment changes rendering an existing arrangement no longer in the child’s best interests. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about a material change in circumstances.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A material change in circumstances exists where facts arising after the entry of the prior order demonstrate that the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests or poses an unreasonable risk to the child’s welfare.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the material-change requirement for modification of custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and identifies the mother’s remarriage (a post‑divorce event) as “plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances.” It explains that changed circumstances are those occurring after the prior judgment and ties that requirement to whether modification is “necessary in the best interests of the children.” This aligns with the proposition that a material change exists where new post‑order facts show the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests or creates risk to the child’s welfare.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce…, the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children… provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’). Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.proposition: The alleged impairment of the Defendant while caring for Ethan, particularly at night and during transportation, poses a risk of harm to Ethan, which constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances since the 2021 Custody Order.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns choosing between two adoptive placements for a child in state custody, applying a best-interests standard and appellate deference. It does not address parental impairment, substance use, nighttime care, transportation risks, or what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ under a prior custody order. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a caregiver’s alleged impairment while caring for a child amounts to a material and substantial change in circumstances.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’"

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.proposition: The Plaintiff acknowledges that it is generally in a child’s best interests to have frequent and continuing contact with both parents, provided such contact is safe and supportive of the child’s physical and emotional health.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection/termination-type case focused on parental unfitness and standards of proof, not on general parenting-time principles. Nowhere does the court state that it is generally in a child’s best interests to have frequent and continuing contact with both parents, even conditionally. Instead, the court affirms permanent custody in the department based on risk of harm and does not articulate any preference for ongoing contact with both parents as a general rule.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.relevant_excerpt: “A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children… Social workers and other professionals… were virtually unanimous in stating that the parents were not presently fit to care for the children and that the children would be in danger of being subjected to emotional and physical harm if returned to the custody of their parents immediately. The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.”

Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.raw_text: Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132, 141 (2004)
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.proposition: A child’s exposure to a caregiver who is intoxicated or otherwise impaired can cause emotional distress, anxiety, and instability, even in the absence of a specific accident or injury.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses harms to children from witnessing domestic violence and cites Custody of Vaughn for the principle that such exposure causes a "distinctly grievous kind of harm." However, this case does not address a child’s exposure to an intoxicated or otherwise impaired caregiver, nor does it discuss emotional distress or instability arising from substance-related impairment absent a specific accident. Its focus is on domestic violence and parental mental health/unfitness, not caregiver intoxication per se.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: In Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595, the court declared that “physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and ... a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.” ... Vaughn cautions, however, that witnessing domestic violence is itself a “grievous” harm. Id. at 595.

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION  (G.L. c. 208, §28; G.L. c. 209C; G.L. c. 215, §6)

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a728, 31.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with Massachusetts statutes and case law requiring that custody and parenting time arrangements be adjusted when circumstances change in ways that materially affect the child’s welfare and best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a710.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with Massachusetts statutes and case law requiring that custody and parenting time arrangements be adjusted when circumstances change in ways that materially affect the child’s welfare and best interests.
